revision.text:
{{Infobox concert |concert_tour_name=The 20/20 Experience World Tour |image=20 Experience World Tour.png |image_size=220px |border=yes |artist=[[Justin Timberlake]] |album={{plain list| *''[[The 20/20 Experience]]'' *''[[The 20/20 Experience – 2 of 2]]'' }} |start_date={{Start date|2013|11|06}} |end_date={{End date|2015|01|02}} |number_of_shows=134 |number_of_legs=6 |gross=$231.6 million |attendance=1.9 million (128 shows) |last_tour=[[Legends of the Summer Stadium Tour]]
(2013) |this_tour='''The 20/20 Experience World Tour'''
(2013–2015) |next_tour=[[The Man of the Woods Tour]]
(2018–2019) }} '''The 20/20 Experience World Tour''' was the fifth [[concert tour]] by American singer-songwriter [[Justin Timberlake]]. It was launched in support of his third and fourth studio albums, ''[[The 20/20 Experience]]'' (2013) and ''[[The 20/20 Experience – 2 of 2]]'' (2013).{{cite web|title=Justin Timberlake Announces '20/20' World Tour|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1560696/justin-timberlake-announces-2020-world-tour|date=May 6, 2013 |accessdate=December 23, 2014 |work=Billboard}} The tour began on November 6, 2013 in New York City, and concluded on January 2, 2015 in [[Las Vegas]]. The 20/20 Experience World Tour grossed $231.6 million from 134 shows becoming the second highest-grossing tour of 2014, behind [[One Direction]]'s [[Where We Are Tour (One Direction)|Where We Are Tour]]{{cite web|title=Live Music's $20 Billion Year: Rolling Stones, One Direction, Live Nation Top Boxscore's Year-End |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6406028/boxscore-top-tours-2014-rolling-stones-live-nation|publisher=Billboard|date=December 12, 2014 |accessdate=December 12, 2014 |last= Waddell | first=Ray}} and one of the [[List of highest-grossing concert tours#2010s|highest-grossing tours of the decade]]. This made Timberlake the highest-grossing solo touring artist of the year.{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/touring/6443514/justin-timberlakes-2020-tour-earned-232-million-in-ticket-sales|title=Justin Timberlake's 20/20 Tour Earned $232 Million in Ticket Sales|date=October 4, 2013|accessdate=June 9, 2014|last= Bob| first= Allen|work=Billboard}} It is also Timberlake's most successful tour to date. Directed by [[Jonathan Demme]], the concert film—titled ''Justin Timberlake + The Tennessee Kids''—premiered on September 13 at the [[2016 Toronto International Film Festival]]. It showcases the final date of the 20/20 tour at Las Vegas’ [[MGM Grand Garden Arena]].{{cite web | url=http://www.indiewire.com/2016/07/tiff-film-list-analysis-toronto-international-film-festival-1201710079/ | title=TIFF Lineup: 5 Reasons to Get Excited About the 2016 Program | work=[[Indie Wire]] | date=July 26, 2016 | accessdate=July 27, 2016}}{{cite web | url=http://uproxx.com/movies/toronto-international-film-festival-2016-schedule/ | title=The 2016 Toronto Film Festival Schedule Has Justin Timberlake, Oscar Contenders, And A Lot Of Amy Adams| work=[[Uproxx]] | date=July 26, 2016 | accessdate=July 27, 2016}} The streaming service [[Netflix]] announced its acquisition ahead of the film's debut at film festival and released it on October 12, 2016.{{cite web | url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/09/09/justin-timberlake-2020-concert-movie-netflix | title=Justin Timberlake 20/20 concert movie dropping on Netflix | work=Entertainment Weekly | date=September 9, 2016 | accessdate=September 9, 2016 | author=Romano, Nick}} It was the final film to be directed by Demme before his death in April 2017. == Critical response == [[File:Justin Timberlake 2014 February 3.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|Timberlake performing in February 2014.]] Since its debut, The 20/20 Experience World Tour has received acclaim from critics.{{cite web | url=http://www.vibe.com/2014/10/justin-timberlake-film-final-2020-experience-world-tour-shows/ | title=Justin Timberlake To Film Final ’20/20 Experience World Tour’ Shows | work=Vibe | date=October 23, 2014 | accessdate=October 11, 2016}} Writing for the ''[[New York Daily News]]'', Jim Farber reviewed the opening show at Barclays Center. Farber described the concert as a "study in suave ease. Starting with '[[Pusher Love Girl]],' Timberlake exuded a sweatless charm."{{cite news|url=http://nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/timberlake-kicks-20-20-experience-tour-barclays-center-article-1.1509258|title=Concert review: Justin Timberlake kicks off '20/20 Experience' tour with flirty gig at Barclays Center|last=Farber|first=Jim|date=2013-11-07|accessdate=2013-11-23|publisher=New York Daily}} Hillary Rea for ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'', who attended the tour at the [[Wells Fargo Center (Philadelphia)|Wells Fargo Center]], noted that Timberlake's performance "kept the audience not just alert, but hypnotized and hooked throughout a 30-song spectacle that ended just before midnight."{{cite news|url=http://articles.philly.com/2013-11-13/entertainment/43935182_1_tennessee-kids-jt-main-stage|title=Timberlake showcases all his moves|last=Rea|first=Hillary|date=2013-11-13|accessdate=2013-11-23|publisher=The Inquirer}} Fionnuala Bourke in a review for ''[[Birmingham Mail]]'' opined that Justin "managed to completely keep his cool amid all the screams" and he "proved his position as the President of Pop."{{cite news|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/whats-on/music-nightlife-news/review-justin-timberlake-lg-arena-6981055|title=Review: Justin Timberlake at LG Arena|last=Bourke|first=Fionnuala|date=2014-04-11|accessdate=2014-12-15|publisher=Birmingham Mail}} ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'''s Emily Zemler, described him as a performer who is "genuinely having fun", adding he "knows he's got the looks, but he is also skilled at delivering something that isn't all surface", about the concert at [[The Forum (Inglewood, California)|The Forum, Los Angeles]]. She added: "Onstage, the pop star and actor moves with the sort of confidence that comes only from this knowledge, where it manifests not as ego but as absolute self-assurance.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/concert-review-justin-timberlake-at-672976|title=Justin Timberlake Touts Suits, Ties and Tequila at Newly Renovated Forum: Concert Review|first=Emily|last=Zemler|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=January 21, 2014|accessdate=March 24, 2015}} Jon Pareles of ''[[The New York Times]]'' also gave a positive review noting that he "reveals something darker" and "something more fiery and intense" while performing post-breakup revenge songs such as "[[Cry Me a River (Justin Timberlake song)|Cry Me a River]]" and "[[What Goes Around... Comes Around]]."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/08/arts/music/justin-timberlake-begins-his-solo-tour-in-brooklyn.html?_r=0|title=Song and Dance, With Groove, Justin Timberlake Begins His Solo Tour in Brooklyn|last=Pareles|first=Jon|date=2013-11-07|accessdate=2014-12-15|publisher=Birmingham Mail}} == Costumes == {{Quote box|width=24%|bgcolor=#ffeeaa|align=right|quote="Justin has great personal style and knows what he wants which makes designing for him an absolute pleasure..."|source=—Tom Ford}} Timberlake worked with [[Tom Ford]] for the tour's costumes.{{cite web|url=http://gq-magazine.co.uk/style/articles/2013-11/07/justin-timberlake-tom-ford-world-tour-wardrobe|title=Still on that suit and tie s***: Tom Ford dresses Justin Timberlake's 20/20 Tour|last=Franklin|first=Oliver|work=GQ|accessdate=November 7, 2013}} During their collaboration they have created more than 600 costumes for Timberlake and his team.{{cite web|url=http://fashionista.com/2013/11/tom-ford-designed-600-pieces-exclusively-for-justin-timberlake/|title=Tom Ford Designed 600 Pieces Exclusively for Justin Timberlake|last=Mccall|first=Tyler|work=GQ|accessdate=November 6, 2013}} Most of Timberlake's costumes are black and white colored suits. ==Broadcast & recordings== [[File:Justin Timberlake Netflix.jpg|thumb|right|Netflix promotional poster for ''Justin Timberlake + The Tennessee Kids'']] The concert film ''Justin Timberlake + The Tennessee Kids'' premiered on [[Netflix]] on October 12, 2016. Prior to premiering at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]], Timberlake dedicated the film to [[Prince (musician)|Prince]]. "His influence is all over everyone's music and there's so much that I feel like I've maybe consciously and unconsciously borrowed from him that it felt right", he told [[E!]] "It just feels right to dedicate the film to him."{{cite web | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7540945/justin-timberlake-says-tennessee-kids-concert-film-debut-made-him-as-nervous-as-ever-been | title=Justin Timberlake Says 'Tennessee Kids' Concert Film Debut Made Him As Nervous As He's Ever Been | work=Billboard | date=October 11, 2016 | accessdate=October 11, 2016 | author=Havens, Lyndsey}} The concert film showcases the final date of the 20/20 tour at Las Vegas' [[MGM Grand Garden Arena]]. Demme and Timberlake first met when the director wanted to work with him after watching his work in ''[[The Social Network]]'' (2010); in the meeting they discussed [[Talking Heads]]' concert film ''[[Stop Making Sense]]'', directed by Demme and an influence for the singer in his live performances.{{cite web | url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/10/11/justin-timberlake-jonathan-demme-interview | title=How Justin Timberlake and Jonathan Demme kept the concert film fresh | work=Entertainment Weekly | date=October 11, 2016 | accessdate=October 12, 2016 | author=Sullivan, Kevin P.}} For ''Justin Timberlake + The Tennessee Kids'', Demme used 14 operated cameras that [[Declan Quinn]], the director of photography, and he deployed over many pre-filming engagements, two other free-floating cameras in the audience and one cameraman onstage with Timberlake.{{cite web | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7541088/jonathan-demme-justin-timberlake-documentary-netflix | title=Jonathan Demme Shares Stories Behind Justin Timberlake, Talking Heads & Neil Young Concert Documentaries | work=Billboard | date=October 12, 2016 | accessdate=October 12, 2016 | author=Bliss, Karen}} Reviewing the concert film, critic David Rooney from ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' wrote:
It's noteworthy that after two years and 134 dates on the 20/20 Experience World Tour, the act is drilled to perfection but never robotic. All six dancers combine precision with a personal signature, as do the musicians and singers who frequently step out from behind their 1940s big band-style JT music stands to cut loose. Timberlake is a magnetic performer who moves with twitchy sensuality in his Tom Ford tux. But I could just as easily have watched bespectacled vocalist Jack E. King III get his groove on all night, since there's nothing quite so ecstatically graceful as a heavy-set dude with funk in his bones.{{cite web | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/7510388/justin-timberlake-tennessee-kids-tour-documentary-review | title=Justin Timberlake Shares the Stage With His Tennessee Kids in Dynamic Tour Documentary: Review | work=Billboard | date=September 14, 2016 | accessdate=October 11, 2016 | author=Rooney, David}}
[[File:Jonathan Demme May 2015.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.6|The concert film was the final project directed by Academy Award-winning filmmaker [[Jonathan Demme]] ''(pictured)''.]] Nigel M. Smith from ''[[The Guardian]]'' noted "his falsetto is on-point throughout, as are his smooth moves – like a blend of [[Frank Sinatra]], [[Michael Jackson]] and Prince, to whom the film is dedicated. There's a sexy swagger to Timberlake's onstage personae that never reads as cocksure, largely because of the lavish attention he pays to his band and dancers... They all look like there's no place they’d rather be, despite it being the end of a grueling two year tour. In an era when machines are largely responsible for the beats that drive pop music, the reverence Timberlake shows for actual instruments is worth endearing. Still, there's no mistaking Timberlake as ring leader."{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/sep/15/justin-timberlake-the-tennessee-kids-review-jonathan-demmes | title=Justin Timberlake + the Tennessee Kids review – Jonathan Demme's no-frills doc | work=The Guardian | date=September 15, 2016 | accessdate=October 11, 2016 | author=Smith, Nigel M.}} Brian Tallerico of the [[Roger Ebert]] website gave the film three-and-a-half out of four stars, and wrote "Demme opens his fantastically entertaining [concert film] by introducing us to the backup players and musicians who have supported the pop star on this two-year tour, but make no mistake, this movie is about the entertainer at its center. While Demme's camera never forgets to allow the other partners in pop to share time, he always comes back to Timberlake, one of the most purely enjoyable musicians around which one could center a concert film. His energy is infectious and his joy about what he's been blessed to do for a living is contagious".{{cite web | url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/justin-timberlake--the-tennessee-kids-2016 | title=Justin Timberlake + The Tennessee Kids | work=Roger Ebert | date=October 11, 2016 | accessdate=October 12, 2016 | author=Tallerico, Brian}} On [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 100%, based on 13 reviews, with an [[Weighted arithmetic mean|average rating]] of 8.1/10.{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/justin_timberlake_the_tennessee_kids/ |title= Justin Timberlake + The Tennessee Kids (2016) |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate=November 12, 2016}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score 81 out of 100, based on 6 reviews, indicating "universal acclaim".{{cite web |title=Justin Timberlake + the Tennessee Kids |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/justin-timberlake-+-the-tennessee-kids |work=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=October 23, 2016}} {{clear}} {{hidden | headercss = background: #ccccff; font-size: 100%; width: 65%; | contentcss = text-align: left; font-size: 100%; width: 65%; | header = Song list | content = #"[[Pusher Love Girl]]" #"[[Gimme What I Don't Know (I Want)]]"/"[[Rock Your Body]]" #"[[Don't Hold the Wall]]"/"[[FutureSex/LoveSound]]" #"[[Like I Love You]]" #"[[My Love (Justin Timberlake song)|My Love]]" #"[[LoveStoned]]" #"[[Until the End of Time (Justin Timberlake and Beyoncé song)|Until the End of Time]]" #"[[Holy Grail (Jay-Z song)|Holy Grail]]" #"Only When I Walk Away" #"[[Drink You Away]]" #"[[Let the Groove Get In]]" #"[[Human Nature (Michael Jackson song)|Human Nature]]" #"[[What Goes Around... Comes Around]]" #"[[Poison (Bell Biv DeVoe song)|Poison]]" #"[[Suit & Tie]]" #"[[SexyBack]]" #"[[Mirrors (Justin Timberlake song)|Mirrors]]" }} == Set list == The following set list is representative of the show on November 6, 2013. It is not representative of all concerts for the duration of the tour. {{div col}} #"[[Pusher Love Girl]]" #"[[Gimme What I Don't Know (I Want)]]" / "[[Rock Your Body]]" #"[[Don't Hold the Wall]]" #"[[FutureSex/LoveSound]]" #"[[Like I Love You]]" #"[[My Love (Justin Timberlake song)|My Love]]" #"[[TKO (Justin Timberlake song)|TKO]]" #"[[Strawberry Bubblegum]]" #"[[Summer Love (Justin Timberlake song)|Summer Love]]" #"[[LoveStoned]]" #"[[Until the End of Time (Justin Timberlake and Beyoncé song)|Until the End of Time]]" #"[[Holy Grail (Jay-Z song)|Holy Grail]]" / "[[Cry Me a River (Justin Timberlake song)|Cry Me a River]]" #"Only When I Walk Away" #"True Blood" #"[[Drink You Away]]" #"[[Tunnel Vision (Justin Timberlake song)|Tunnel Vision]]" #"[[Señorita (Justin Timberlake song)|Señorita]]" #"[[Let the Groove Get In]]" #"[[Heartbreak Hotel]]" #"[[Not a Bad Thing]]" #"[[Human Nature (Michael Jackson song)|Human Nature]]" #"[[What Goes Around... Comes Around]]" #"[[Cabaret (Justin Timberlake song)|Cabaret]]" #"[[Take Back the Night (song)|Take Back the Night]]" #"[[Jungle Boogie]]" / "Murder" / "[[Poison (Bell Biv DeVoe song)|Poison]]" #"[[Suit & Tie]]" #"[[SexyBack]]" ;Encore #
